question_details.query: In trawl fisheries, what are the most effective gear modifications for reducing unwanted fish catch?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates several trawl-gear modifications reduced unwanted fish catch in multiple studies: (1) Combining square-mesh escape panels/windows with size‑sorting grids in bottom trawls reduced unwanted catches of fish, sharks and rays, and total discards in four of five replicated paired/controlled studies across the Gulf of Carpentaria, Indian Ocean and Atlantic Ocean; effectiveness varied by species/size and panel position, and whiting size‑selectivity increased when panels/cylinders were combined with one or two grids in the English Channel (action 2727). (2) Fitting a size‑sorting mesh funnel (sieve net) to shrimp trawls reduced catches of unwanted (non‑commercial/discarded) fish in three replicated paired controlled studies in the North Sea (action 2722). (3) Using topless (coverless) trawls reduced unwanted Atlantic cod and discards of commercial fish species in two of four replicated controlled studies, with size‑dependent effects for haddock and cod in one study (action 2712). (4) Fitting rigid escape windows/panels reduced catches of unwanted flatfish in one replicated paired controlled study in the Baltic Sea (action 2719). (5) Decreasing codend circumference/diameter improved size‑selectivity for several species in four of eight replicated controlled studies and one review, and reduced discarded fish or total discards in some cases but not others across multiple regions (action 2706). (6) Switching to a square‑mesh rather than diamond‑mesh codend reduced non‑commercial unwanted invertebrates in one of two areas, with similar catches in the other, while maintaining similar commercial fish catches and sometimes higher shellfish catches (action 2136).
summary_statements: Several trawl-gear modifications have been shown to reduce unwanted fish catch in multiple studies.
Combining square-mesh escape panels or windows with size-sorting grids in bottom trawls reduced unwanted catches of fish, sharks, and rays.
The combination of square-mesh escape panels with size-sorting grids in bottom trawls reduced total discards in studies across the Gulf of Carpentaria, Indian Ocean, and Atlantic Ocean.

Whiting size-selectivity in the English Channel increased when escape panels or cylinders were combined with one or two size-sorting grids.

What are the conservation benefits of prohibiting spearfishing in marine reserves in the Mediterranean?

summary_details.relevant_summary: In the Mediterranean, prohibiting spearfishing (often alongside line fishing) in marine reserves has been associated with higher abundances of targeted fish such as European seabass and gilthead seabream after two to seven years [2672]. It has also been associated with larger sizes of European seabass in protected areas compared to fished areas over similar time frames [2672]. Comparisons between spearfished and non-spearfished areas 10–12 years after implementation reported differences in fish densities related to depth and/or fish size [2672]. Additionally, zones within a Mediterranean marine reserve that prohibited spearfishing saw higher commercial and recreational catches of targeted common dentex than zones allowing spearfishing and areas outside the reserve after one to three years [2672].
summary_statements: In the Mediterranean, prohibiting spearfishing in marine reserves has been associated with higher abundances of targeted fish such as European seabass and gilthead seabream after two to seven years.

question_details.query: What are the effects on marine fish populations of prohibiting different types of bottom fishing gear?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Prohibiting mobile bottom-towed gears dragged across the seafloor was associated with higher total fish biomass after 15 years, larger adult red mullet after 14 years, and increased abundances of long‑snouted seahorses after one year, though several studies reported no change in overall fish abundance, average fish weight, or species richness/diversity, and haddock recruitment and survival did not increase seven years post‑closure; recruitment increased for young red mullet after 14 years (2673). Prohibiting all bottom gears (mobile and static) was associated with higher numbers of larger and older cod after 15 years and improved cod growth after 5–15 years, while fish densities showed mixed responses, varying by species/group and environmental factors, and in some cases showed no differences after 2–7 years (2654).

question_details.query: What are some alternatives to setting catch quotas for controlling fishing mortality?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Alternatives documented in the action evidence include: effort controls such as limiting the number of fishing days, which in one Mediterranean study was followed by higher biomass of thornback and brown rays (3804), and restricting fishing activity by vessel size/engine power, where excluding higher-power vessels for part of each year was followed by higher abundance of commercially targeted fish, with effects varying by fish size groups (3809); limiting fisher/vessel numbers via permits/licences is proposed but had no direct evaluation found (3817), as did limits on the number or length of static nets (3808) and limits on traps/pots per vessel (3807). Spatial–temporal measures include temporary closures, which showed mixed outcomes: cod biomass, survival and length composition did not increase versus fished areas, tagged cod spent about a third of time inside a seasonal spawning closure, real-time closures reduced the annual amount of cod caught, and some targeted fisheries saw increased catch rates after closures (2664); other temporary closures affected non-fish taxa, including reduced lethal turtle strandings and fishery shutdowns when turtle bycatch limits were reached (3545), and for benthic invertebrates produced varied changes in abundance and condition when areas were temporarily closed or reopened (2098). Long-term closures showed mixed fish responses but included reductions in unwanted cod catch when combined with gear-limited areas and reduced overall fishing effort for sandeel (2655). Size-based regulations include minimum landing sizes, where evidence on recruitment and discards was mixed, with some reductions in catches of the youngest fish in one case and persistence of immature fish in landings in another (2735); size limits for recreational species lacked direct evaluations for invertebrates (2274). Gear selectivity modifications offer alternatives to reduce mortality of non-target or undersized fish, such as fitting trawl nets with escape panels/windows and size-sorting grids, which reduced unwanted catches and improved size-selectivity in multiple studies (2727, 2725, 2721).

question_details.query: What does the evidence say about how different fishing practices affect the survival of fish after capture and release?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates: Reducing air exposure before release did not increase survival of small-spotted catshark caught by trawling, but shorter air exposure improved physical condition and reduced injury of discarded chum salmon, and minimal air exposure and handling improved post-release behaviour of reef fish (2690). Releasing captured fish alive resulted in the majority (76–92%) of several species surviving at least 1 h–5 days, though less than half of smooth skate survived; survival was reduced by injuries related to hooking/capture depth and by longer tow durations; nearly all yelloweye rockfish survived 4 days post-release while canary rockfish survival decreased with increasing capture depth; devilrays survived when brailed aboard from purse seines but not when brought aboard entangled (2691). Establishing handling and release protocols with minimal handling/air exposure led to faster returns to reef/seabed for reef fish, and tracked whale sharks released using an enhanced purse-seine protocol survived at least 21 days with normal movements (2692). Using different hook types reduced hook injuries associated with higher post-release mortality and reduced capture mortality for some unwanted sharks and rays and some non-target billfish, though other studies found no reduction in mortality; some studies reported reduced deep-hooking without mortality reduction (2698). Modifying longline configuration produced mixed survival outcomes for unwanted sharks: one global review reported higher survival on nylon hook attachments for two of three species and lower for one, while one field study found reduced survival on nylon compared to wire (2699). Using hook-and-line instead of other commercial gear produced greater vitality (an indicator of post-release survival) than other gear types (2732).

question_details.query: How do the effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish abundance vary across different ocean basins?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple ocean basins, studies report varied effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish abundance. In the Mediterranean Sea, site comparisons reported no increase in biomass for some targeted species 2–13 years after closure compared to a fished area, while other studies in this and additional basins recorded higher abundances for subsets of species (e.g., some commercially targeted and non-targeted groups) [2667]. In the Indian Ocean and Gulf of Mexico, among site comparison studies, some found higher abundances for parts of the fish community, while others reported mixed outcomes across species/groups [2667]. In the South Atlantic Ocean, one study found no change in fish species composition relative to fished areas, and among abundance-focused comparisons spanning this and other basins, responses ranged from higher abundances in some commercially exploited species to mixed effects depending on exploitation history [2667]. In the Tasman Sea, a before-and-after study found lower abundances for most species two years after closure in an estuary, while another study in a reserve zone closed to commercial trapping reported abundance patterns that varied over a decade and among fish groups [2667]. In the South China Sea, overall fish density in the wider region increased within five years after reserves limiting commercial fishing were created, alongside shifts in assemblage composition [2667]. Syntheses and multi-region studies of fully non-fished marine protected areas across the Indian, Atlantic, Mediterranean, Pacific, Tasman, Coral, Philippine, and Caribbean seas, as well as the Gulf of Mexico and Sulu Sea, frequently found higher total fish abundance/biomass and higher abundances of many targeted and non-targeted species compared to fished or partially fished areas, though several studies reported similar or species-dependent effects, with variability linked to species group, trophic position, fish size, depth, habitat, and protected area age/size [2682].
summary_statements: Studies report varied effects of prohibiting all commercial fishing on fish abundance across multiple ocean basins.

question_details.query: What are the most effective non-gear-modification strategies for reducing unwanted fish catch?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on non-gear-modification strategies for reducing unwanted fish catch includes: Establishing move-on rules that trigger temporary closures when catch thresholds are reached was associated with lower overall cod discards in a replicated, controlled, before-and-after study (3815). Using technology to communicate near real-time catch information to fishers was reported to reduce unwanted catch or discards in two of three cases in a review (3826). Setting catch limits or quotas for non-targeted commercial species reduced unwanted catch in two of three cases in a review, and a before-and-after study found catch limits reduced unwanted halibut whereas a previous individual transferable quota system did not (2693). Implementing a combination of long-term fishery closures and areas limited to specific gears reduced unwanted catch of cod in a replicated, before-and-after study (2655). Implementing a combination of prohibiting non-selective gear types and long-term closures reduced unwanted catch of cod in a replicated, before-and-after study (3810).
summary_statements: Establishing move-on rules that trigger temporary closures when catch thresholds are reached was associated with lower overall cod discards.

question_details.query: What management actions are available to specifically protect the reproductive capacity of fish populations?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Relevant management actions identified in the action documents include: protecting spawning fish from capture, typically via seasonal or permanent closures of spawning/nursery areas; studies reported no increase in Atlantic cod spawning stock biomass or survival nine years after a seasonal closure, while tagged adult cod spent nearly a third of time inside a seasonally closed spawning area and young school sharks used closed nursery areas extensively [2938]. Establishing temporary fishery closures; one study found no increase in cod spawning stock biomass, survival, or length composition over nine years, but tagged cod spent nearly a third of time inside a closed spawning area during implementation, and real-time area closures reduced annual cod catch (retained and discarded) [2664]. Ceasing or prohibiting all fishing in marine protected areas (no-take zones); multiple studies found higher abundances and larger fish compared to fished areas, and one study found more eggs of four commercially targeted species inside a non-fished reserve than outside [2682]. Setting minimum landing sizes for commercially fished species; one review reported increased swordfish recruitment in one of five fisheries after recommended minimum sizes and catch limits, whereas a replicated study reported most fish landed were immature despite minimum sizes, and other studies showed mixed effects on unwanted catch [2735]. Setting maximum landing sizes for commercially fished species; no studies currently evaluate effects [2736]. Releasing fish that are carrying eggs or live young; no studies currently evaluate effects [2733]. Releasing protected or species of concern alive after capture; replicated studies reported majority short-term survival (76–92%) in several species, with survival influenced by depth-related injuries and tow duration, while some species experienced lower survival or gear-related mortality [2691].

question_details.query: What is the state of evidence for the effectiveness of involving fishers and other stakeholders in marine conservation management?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Three studies on involving fishers and stakeholders in co-management reported mixed outcomes: one before-and-after study in the Indian Ocean found increased overall fish abundance nine years after implementation, though responses varied among species groups; in the Pacific (Tonga), five years after a new co-management system there was no decrease in overall fishing effort and no increase in total fish catch rates, with decreases for half of six species groups; in the South China Sea (Vietnam), illegal fishing using destructive gears decreased after co-management was established [2910]. Evidence gaps were reported for several related stakeholder-involvement actions: no studies evaluated engaging fishers in scientific data collection on marine fish populations [2813]; no studies evaluated involving stakeholders in the allocation of harvest rights on marine fish populations [2812]; no studies evaluated including fishers in MPA management fora on marine fish populations [2809]; no studies evaluated involving fishers in designing/trialling new selective gear on marine fish populations [2810]; no studies evaluated promoting knowledge exchange between fishers to improve good practice on marine fish populations [2814]; and no studies evaluated engaging stakeholders when designating MPAs on subtidal benthic invertebrate populations [2243].

question_details.query: What are the most effective operational tactics for fishers to reduce unwanted catch without modifying the main structure of their nets or lines?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates: Using technology to share near real-time catch information with fishers was associated with reductions in unwanted catch or discards in two of three reported cases in the North Pacific and North Atlantic Oceans [3826]. Establishing move-on rules that delay or relocate fishing when mammals are encountered, combined with releasing trapped animals, resulted in fewer short-beaked common dolphins being encircled and killed in the Great Australian Bight [2790]. Establishing temporary fishery closures was associated with fewer lethal strandings of loggerhead and Kemp’s ridley turtles during seasonal shrimp trawl closures in the USA, and swordfish longline fisheries were closed when annual turtle bycatch limits were reached after reopening, limiting further bycatch for the remainder of those years [3545]. For several operational approaches, the evidence base was reported as absent: selectively avoiding unwanted fish based on temperature distribution [2685], using remote tools to detect mammals and altering vessel course or speed [2757], and using human observers onboard vessels to monitor catches and discards [2740].
summary_statements: Using technology to share near real-time catch information with fishers was associated with reductions in unwanted catch or discards in the North Pacific and North Atlantic Oceans.

question_details.query: Which modifications to trawl nets appear most effective for improving size-selectivity?
What are the documented effects of different restrictions on line fishing, such as prohibitions or gear modifications, on fish populations and unwanted catch?

summary_details.relevant_summary: A site comparison in South Africa reported that prohibiting offshore line fishing (and other boat-based fishing) in a marine protected area zone was associated with higher abundance and larger sizes of four line‑exploited fish species compared to zones where line and spear fishing were permitted [2671]. Modifying longline configuration showed mixed effects: increasing lead weight or using nylon instead of wire reduced unwanted shark/ray catches in some fisheries or reviews, but one study found no reduction in undersized haddock; survival of unwanted sharks/rays at retrieval was higher on nylon than wire for some species in a review, whereas a field study found reduced survival on nylon vs wire [2699]. Changing bait type often reduced unwanted catches of undersized haddock, Atlantic cod and other non‑target fish in several replicated studies, but had no reduction for pelagic stingray or overall unwanted fish in others; two global reviews found no effect on unwanted shark/ray catches; using different bait did not reduce hooking injuries or increase survival of undersized snapper or sharks/rays, and one study reported increased size‑selectivity for Greenland halibut [2700]. Replacing J‑hooks with circle hooks generally reduced sea turtle bycatch in multiple studies and a review, with similar survival in some studies but fewer deep or swallowed hooks and, in one review, fewer turtle deaths in most of the assessed fisheries; effects varied among fisheries and with bait type [3559]. Evidence for seabird bycatch mitigation on longlines is variable: one Australian study found lower bycatch with bait throwers [291]; a North Pacific trial recorded higher bycatch with a line shooter while a Norwegian trial found no effect [290]; no intervention-based evidence was found for high‑visibility longlines or water cannons [294, 287]. Using non‑ringed circle hooks in a Mediterranean swordfish longline fishery reduced loggerhead turtle catch compared to ringed hooks [3576].

question_details.query: In prawn and shrimp trawl fisheries, what gear modifications are available to reduce the unwanted catch of fish?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents identifies the following gear modifications used in prawn/shrimp trawl fisheries to reduce unwanted fish catch: fitting size‑sorting escape grids (rigid or flexible) to prawn/shrimp trawl nets, which in many studies reduced unwanted fish and total unwanted catch (Action ID: 2721); installing size‑sorting mesh funnels/sieve nets in shrimp trawls, which reduced catches of unwanted fish in replicated, paired, controlled trials (Action ID: 2722); adding large, supported escape openings such as Fisheyes, Bigeyes, or radial escape sections to trawl nets, which reduced overall unwanted fish, immature red snapper, and total unwanted catch, and reduced unwanted shark catch in one study (Action ID: 2723); combining square‑mesh escape panels/windows with size‑sorting grids in trawl nets, which reduced unwanted fish, sharks and rays, and total discards in several studies, with escape occurring via the panel and/or grid depending on species and size (Action ID: 2727); modifying the design/attachments of shrimp/prawn W‑trawl nets, which caught less non‑commercial unwanted crustacean bycatch than a traditional trawl (Action ID: 2139). Additional trawl gear changes that can reduce unwanted fish catches or improve size‑selectivity include using topless/coverless trawls, which reduced discards or unwanted catches of some commercial species in several studies (Action ID: 2712); using different designs/configurations of size‑sorting escape grids/systems, which in some cases reduced unwanted catches or improved size‑selectivity depending on species and conditions (Action ID: 2728); rotating diamond‑mesh orientation in codends by 90°, which improved size‑selection for several round‑bodied fish species (Action ID: 2715); modifying the configuration (position/size or mesh size) of mesh escape panels/windows, which reduced unwanted catches of some species or improved size‑selectivity in some cases (Action ID: 2717); and decreasing codend circumference/diameter, which in some studies reduced discarded fish catches and in others improved size‑selectivity for multiple species (Action ID: 2706).

question_details.query: What is the evidence for gear modifications improving the size-selectivity of commercial fishing gear?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Replicated, controlled studies report that various trawl-gear design changes (e.g., extension length, strengthening bag, weaving method, codend layers, overall design) improved size‑selectivity for unwanted fish and annular seabream in the North Sea and Mediterranean [2704]. Alternative designs/configurations of size‑sorting escape grids in trawls improved size‑selectivity for unwanted redfish, Greenland halibut, and target hake in some cases, with other studies showing species‑specific outcomes or no improvement [2728]. Decreasing trawl codend circumference/diameter improved size‑selectivity for haddock, Atlantic cod, whiting, European hake, and red mullet in several studies and a review, though effects varied among species and could be reduced for one species [2706]. In encircling nets, transparent netting panels improved size‑selectivity for one of four commercial fish species [2703]. Modified traps/pots with square‑mesh escape windows or larger mesh improved size‑selectivity for Atlantic cod, black sea bass, and most species tested, though one study found no effect for panga [2702]. Adding moving stimulator devices alongside square‑mesh escape panels improved cod size‑selectivity for one of three device types in the Baltic Sea [2729]. Some modifications showed no improvement: reducing the main trawl body size did not improve size‑selection of cod and haddock [2705], and LED lights on a size‑sorting grid did not improve size‑selectivity for long rough dab, Atlantic cod, haddock, and redfish [2695].

question_details.query: What are the documented ecological outcomes of managing small-scale traditional fisheries, either through prohibition or by making them the only permitted fishing type?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Allowing only small-scale traditional (artisanal) fishing in a marine protected area zone for three years was associated with higher overall commercial catch rates for five of seven species compared to openly fished areas (2678).
- Prohibiting all fishing with limited exceptions in marine protected areas produced mixed fish community and population responses: lower total fish species richness in some areas compared to unprotected sites; similar biomass and lower total fish density when only bait fishing was allowed; similar abundance for several rockfish species and lingcod relative to fished sites; increased cod survival inside the protected area; and frequent, prolonged use of protected habitats by some shark species, reducing likelihood of fishing mortality (2681).
- Closing areas to all non-towed (static) fishing gears was associated with higher overall shark abundance when sampled with longlines (but not with gillnets) and greater length for two of five shark species/groups compared to areas permitting commercial gillnets (2670).
- Prohibiting commercial fishing was associated with different benthic invertebrate community composition relative to fished areas; no change in overall invertebrate species richness in one case; greater overall invertebrate abundance in closed areas in two cases, with biomass higher in one and similar in another; no difference in lobster abundance after up to two years; and greater biological production from invertebrates where trawling and dredging had been excluded for 28 years (2097).
